section_1_key_concepts.overview: Cells are the basic building blocks of all living organisms. This topic covers the structure and function of eukaryotic and prokaryotic cells, and how to use microscopy to observe them.

key_terms.definition: A cell with a nucleus and membrane-bound organelles (e.g., animal and plant cells)
A simpler cell without a true nucleus (e.g., bacteria)
The organelle where aerobic respiration takes place
The site of protein synthesis in the cell
key_terms.importance: Makes all proteins the cell needs

key_terms.definition: A semi-permeable barrier controlling what enters and leaves the cell

learning_objectives: Describe the structure of eukaryotic and prokaryotic cells
Explain the function of each organelle
Use a microscope and calculate magnification
Compare animal, plant, and bacterial cells
Understand the scale of cells and units of measurement

section_2_detailed_explanations.heading: Animal and Plant Cells
section_2_detailed_explanations.content: Both animal and plant cells are eukaryotic. They share: nucleus (contains DNA), cell membrane, cytoplasm, mitochondria, and ribosomes. Plant cells additionally have: cell wall (cellulose), permanent vacuole (filled with cell sap), and chloroplasts (for photosynthesis).
key_points: Both types have nucleus, membrane, cytoplasm, mitochondria, ribosomes
Plant cells also have cell wall, vacuole, chloroplasts
Not all plant cells have chloroplasts (e.g., root cells)

section_2_detailed_explanations.heading: Prokaryotic Cells (Bacteria)
section_2_detailed_explanations.content: Prokaryotic cells are much smaller (1-5 μm vs 10-100 μm) and simpler. They have: cell membrane, cytoplasm, ribosomes (smaller), cell wall, and a single DNA loop (not enclosed in a nucleus). Some have plasmids (small rings of extra DNA) and flagella (tail for movement).
key_points: No true nucleus — DNA floats freely
Cell wall is NOT made of cellulose

section_2_detailed_explanations.heading: Microscopy and Magnification
section_2_detailed_explanations.content: Magnification = Image size ÷ Actual size. Light microscopes magnify up to ×1500 with a resolution of 200nm. Electron microscopes magnify up to ×2,000,000 with resolution of 0.2nm. Units: 1mm = 1000μm, 1μm = 1000nm.
key_points: Formula: M = I ÷ A (magnification = image ÷ actual)
Light microscopes use light; electron microscopes use electrons

section_3_worked_examples.question: A cell is 0.05mm long. Under a microscope, it appears 25mm. What is the magnification?
step_by_step: Write the formula: M = I ÷ A
common_mistakes: Forgetting to use the same units

foundation.question: Which organelle controls what enters and leaves the cell?
foundation.explanation: The cell membrane is semi-permeable and controls substance movement

foundation.question: Name two organelles found in plant cells but NOT in animal cells
foundation.correct_answer: Cell wall and chloroplasts (or permanent vacuole)
foundation.explanation: Plant cells have cell wall, chloroplasts, and a permanent vacuole that animal cells lack

higher.question: An image of a cell is 30mm. The magnification is ×600. Calculate the actual size in μm.

command_words.meaning: Give an account of the main features
Work out using numbers — show working

exam_tips: Always state units in magnification questions
When comparing cells, use a table format
common_mistakes: Saying plant cells don't have mitochondria (they do!)
Confusing cell wall and cell membrane
mark_scheme_notes: Calculation marks: M1 for formula, M1 for substitution, A1 for answer with units

revision_checklist: I can label animal and plant cell diagrams

answers.model_answer: Cell membrane — it is semi-permeable and controls the passage of substances into and out of the cell
answers.examiner_tip: Don't confuse with cell wall which provides structural support
